title: Facebook Moves To Dismiss Antitrust Lawsuits
text: Facebook made its first legal move since the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and 46 states filed lawsuits against it in December 2020, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday (March 10). The social media giant asked a federal judge in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C.

title: Facebook Seeks Dismissal Of Antitrust Lawsuits
text: The social network argued in court filings its acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp haven't caused consumers harm.

title: Facebook challenges FTC's antitrust case with big tech's tattered playbook
text: Facebook has challenged the FTC's antitrust case against it using a standard playbook that questions the agency's arguably expansive approach to defining monopolies. But the old arguments of “we're not a monopoly because we never raised prices” and “how can it be anticompetitive if we never allowed competition” may soon be challenged by new doctrine […]

title: Facebook asks judge to throw out antitrust lawsuits filed by FTC and state attorneys general
text: Facebook has motioned to dismiss two lawsuits that aim to break up the tech giant. The firm filed motions asking to dismiss lawsuits filed by the Federal Trade Commission and 48 state attorneys general on December 9. The suits alleged Facebook neutralizes competitors — like by buying WhatsApp and Instagram — before they can threaten the social media giant's dominance.

title: Facebook wants court to dismiss antitrust lawsuits
text: The social media giant has been accused of illegally stifling competition and harming consumers.

title: Facebook asks federal judge to dismiss antitrust lawsuits by FTC, state AGs
text: The 44-page filing is Facebook's first legal salvo since the FTC and 46 states sued the company in December on charges Facebook unlawfully preserved monopoly status by freezing out and buying up potential competitors such as Instagram and WhatsApp.

title: Facebook Reintroduces Instagram Lite In 170 Low Bandwidth Countries: Reuters
text: Facebook Inc (NASDAQ: FB) launched Instagram Lite for Android-based phones in 170 low bandwidth countries to enable photo and video sharing social networking service, Reuters reports. The app requires just 2MB compared to Instagram's 30MB.

title: Facebook asks court to dismiss U.S. government, states antitrust cases
text: Facebook asked a federal court on Wednesday to dismiss major antitrust cases filed by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and nearly every U.S. state, saying they failed to show the company had a monopoly or harmed consumers.

title: Facebook Short Interest Surges 9% to 25 Million Shares
text: Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) may still be at odds with Apple over the tracking of users, but like Google it did make nice with Australia last month over the issue of news aggregation.

title: Biden administration hires more critics of Big Tech
text: President Biden is peppering his administration with some of the most lauded critics of Big Tech, with a British-born legal scholar now tipped for a role at the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Facebook targets emerging markets with the launch of Instagram Lite, an Android app that takes up just 2MB, in 170 countries
text: Growth for Facebook is coming from the developing world, and so the social network today made another key move to cater better to consumers in those countries. After nearly three years in the planning, Facebook is taking the plunge today and officially launching Instagram Lite, a less data- and storage-intensive Android-only version of one of […]

title: Facebook pushes further into developing countries with Instagram Lite
text: The slimmed-down version of Instagram uses less data and is rolling out in more than 170 countries.

title: Tesla, FAANG-Led Nasdaq Rebound Unlikely To Last For Long, Wharton Professor Warns
text: The recent tech-led rebound seen on the Nasdaq may be short-lived, according to Jeremy Siegel, a finance professor at the Wharton School, CNBC reported Tuesday. What Happened: Siegel was less than upbeat on the tech-heavy index, which gained nearly 3.7% on Tuesday to cap the best day since November.
